noData.1: Confirm that uploads for {{name}} either (a) include a consistent site_id column, or (b) are sent via the “Upload CSV for this site” button so CEI can route rows automatically.
noData.2: Check that timestamps for this site actually land in the last 24 hours – older backfills won’t drive this view.
noData.3: Start with one or two key meters for this site (e.g. main incomer, compressors) and validate that their profiles look realistic.

high.1: Identify which hours at {{name}} show the highest kWh and coordinate with production to move non-critical loads away from those peaks.
high.2: Review night and weekend consumption at {{name}} – look for lines, compressors, or HVAC that stay energized with no production.
high.3: Compare today’s kWh profile for {{name}} with a “good” reference day to spot abnormal peaks or extended high-load periods.

medium.1: Check whether batch processes at {{name}} are overlapping more than necessary and see if start times can be staggered.
medium.2: Look for a flat, elevated overnight baseline at {{name}}; that often hides idle losses from utilities and auxiliary equipment.
medium.3: Use CEI to mark any operational changes at {{name}} (setpoint shifts, maintenance) and compare before/after daily kWh.

low.1: {{name}} is running with relatively modest daily energy use. Focus on preventing creeping standby losses over the next weeks.
low.2: Use this site as a low-risk sandbox: test small changes (lighting, idle modes, scheduling) and capture the before/after impact.

common.1: Work with the local team at {{name}} to tag meters by process (e.g. "compressors", "HVAC", "ovens") so future analytics can surface process-level waste.
common.2: Add a quick weekly stand-up for {{name}} where you review this page with operations and agree on one concrete action item.
common.3: Capture photos or notes of any physical changes you make (insulation, setpoints, shutdown procedures) so savings are auditable, not just anecdotal.

title.perSite: Upload timeseries data for this site

subtitle.global: Drag a CSV into CEI and we'll ingest energy readings into the timeseries engine. Column order doesn't matter as long as the headers include timestamp, value, unit, site_id, and meter_id.
subtitle.perSite: You’re uploading data for {{forcedSiteId}}. CEI will ingest all rows into this site. Column order doesn’t matter; the engine reads the header row. For this scoped upload, your CSV must include at least timestamp, value, unit, and meter_id. A site_id column is optional and will be ignored for routing.

csvUpload.scopedMode: Scoped mode: all ingested rows will use site_id = {{forcedSiteId}}.

form.mappingIntro: CEI will read the header row and map columns by name. The engine expects at least:
form.meterIdHint: e.g. meter-main-1 (if omitted, CEI will default to a generic meter id)

tips.title: Tips for smooth ingestion
tips.item1: Keep timestamps in a single timezone per file.
tips.item2Base: Use stable site_id values so dashboards can build trends over time.
tips.item2Scoped: For this scoped upload CEI will enforce {{forcedSiteId}} on every row.
tips.item3: If you backfill older data, it will not change the “last 24 hours” KPIs but will appear in broader windows later.
